Description: Rim, body, and handle sherd (mended from four fragments) of Vroulian pottery shallow cup with short, sharply everted rim; glazed black; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed below; on wall, upper parts of two widely-separated incised upright palmettes or rosettes with alternate fronds in added red and double incised scalloped outline; exterior: upper parts of five incised upright palmettes with alternate fronds in red and double incised scalloped lines framing top; two incised volutes of possible pendant palmette to right of handle.
Curator's comments: Kinch, Vroulia (1914), p. 182, fig. 64, gives Kameiros on Rhodes (via Billiotti and Salzmann) as the provenance of this piece; however, there is no way to prove either Naukratis or Kameiros as the findspot. Kinch places the sherd within his Group B; the lack of a reserved handle zone further suggests that the sherd belongs within his Group B 2.α or .β of Vroulian cups. It is impossible to determine to which of the two groups the cup belongs since the defining characteristic is found on the underside of the stemmed foot, which is now lost.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GN.11) (phase 3)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 163 note 20)
